Posts.Content: I finished Rt at the end of December and still have pain between lumpectomy and nodes scare. I had my 6 months after treatment checkup and was NOT told it was lymphodema of the breast, although its got all the hallmarks of it, Chrystaljuju. I was given a leaflet with an 8 step lymphmassage 'self help'. I also went to my 7th appointment for the study with he lymphodema clinic and was told all was well but they never even looked at my breast just measured arm, although I said how much it hurt. I can't  really do much more, I had twice advice from experts.  Hope you can get yours sorted out. I would be interested what advice you get.
Posts.Title: question

Posts.Content: Hello Jackie, there are a few of us TN girls on here. You have done so well, the tumor has shrunk completely. Mine shrunk from 2 cm to 13 cm, also well done to complete your chemo, I could not do the last two Ts. I found the lumpectomy and radiotherapy easy compared to the chemo. I finished with all my treatment on 31st December and my first mamography showed 'no worrying features' I belong to a facebook site called: Trippe Negative Cancer Survivors. It's an american site, but really friendly and people from all over the world belong to it. There are many long term survivors on it.  I wish all the best with your upcoming operation.
Posts.Title: Any Triple Negative survivors willing to calm me down!!??

Posts.Content: What treatment did you receive, Emma. Chemo again? If yes, was it as bad as the first time round?
Posts.Title: Pedal to the metal!

Posts.Content: Hello Emma, what an amazing story, thank you Deamthief for posting the link. And also how great that you recovered so well from secondaries. I think we are all afraid of this, but great to know that there is a light after that tunnel. I was ready to give up if that would happen to me, but I have renewed hope if that bombshell comes my way.  I wish you all the best, dear Emma.
Posts.Title: Pedal to the metal!

Posts.Content: Exactly, how are we to know? I finished treatment end of December, no further meds for Triple Negative. My breast feels so funny, numb and most of the time quite weird!
Posts.Title: How are you supposed to know

Posts.Content: Hello Shirls, my oncologist warned me before I started Radiotheraphy, that some of her ladies complain about being breathless.  She said it's because the lung can get affected and the radiotheraphy can reduce the lung capacity, the rest of the lung will take over and you will be able to breath ok again after a while. I hope this helps.
Posts.Title: radiotherapy- breathlessness

Posts.Content: Well done, it's such a good feeling.
Posts.Title: DONE IT !!!

Posts.Content: Great, well done to you Denise and your two daughters. Xxx
Posts.Title: Race for Life done and dusted ....

Posts.Content: I saw the Video Blog of VIctoria but somehow felt it was a little on the flippant side, kind of: what are you talking about, this is easy peasy!  Do you know if she has to have chemo? Did it say in the Hello Magazine?
Posts.Title: Anybody else been Victoria Derbyshired????????

Posts.Content: Hello Mildredthecat,  I know what you mean, every pain and I thought it's secondaries. But I am getting better, learning to trust my body again. I asked about a CT scan, but they don't do it, I am not sure if it is expense or the radiation?  I went to four 'Moving On Sessions' and we were told if we have a pain, cough etc. longer than 2 weeks (I was told initially 4 weeks) we have to contact the breast care nurse (we can by pass the GP for 5 years).  You are on Tamoxifen, which is good. For quite a few of us with Triple Negative, there is no further treatment. It sounds like your cancer was caught early, so don't worry, learn to trust your body again which has its own healing mechanism.  I send you lots of good wishes also for you caring for your husband.
Posts.Title: Cant stop worrying about secondaries

Posts.Content: I so much agree with you, MODERATION: I wondered if I should go on a Kale juice diet with flaxseeds!! Now apparenty kale has too much metall and flaxseed hormones which are bad for you. I am so glad I just have a bit of everything I fancy.
Posts.Title: Measures to prevent breast cancer recurrence

Posts.Content: I so much agree with you, MODERATION: I wondered if I should go on a Kale juice diet with flaxseeds!! Now apparenty kale has too much metall and flaxseed hormones which are bad for you. I am so glad I just have a bit of everything I fancy.
Posts.Title: Measures to prevent breast cancer recurrence

Posts.Content: Hi Bev, i had an abscess on a tooth and also fever, so had to go on an antibiotic drip for four days. It cleared up quite quickly. My oncologist was reluctant to let me have any invasive trestment. But perhaps, once infection is cleared up your dentist can fill it with temporary filling like Peepee said. I send you my best wishes.
Posts.Title: bad tooth

Posts.Content: Hello Anna, i had a better response to the T, my tumour shrunk most. But I couldn't tolerate side effects. FEC was much easier. But I met a lady on our Moving on course, who was much more comfortable with T. I would see how you feel, what side effects you have. i send you lots of good wishes.
Posts.Title: Not having full FEC moved into T

Posts.Content: Hello to all, so glad I for this thread. At least I am not the only one suffering, although I would prefer that we would all be well. My lumpectomy plus lymphnode clearance was 6 month ago, I was also TRiple Negative. I am in pain if I wear a bra, have now resorted to wearing work out tops with built in extra support. And I am so tired, if I don't take a nap in the afternoon I could just cry with tiredness in the evening. And then it's the fear of getting cording and lumpectomy. All my friends and family think I am Ok, but I am not. I send you all lots of good wishes.
Posts.Title: Breast pain and low energy 8 months on.

Posts.Content: Dear Carly, yes what a lovely daughter in law you are. I am 66, nine years younger and they never gave me an option. I had Chemo before the Op, then radiotheraphy. Have they mentioned radiotherapy? I found Chemo hard but Radiotherapy quite easy. Perhaps she could just have RT.  As you and Mistymoley say, she has to make the decision. If I could go back and make the decision myself I would go for it, especially if she hasn't many health issues. The team will keep an eye on her and if she suffers too much they will reduce the dose or omit the last session or two. In the great scheme of things 18 weeks are not that long. She then does not have to tell herself: if I only had.....! But take this advice with a pinch of salt, I am only a lay person.  I wish you a good decision which is right for Your Mum in law.
Posts.Title: Chemo Decisions

Posts.Content: Hello Posh, you seem to be a very tough girl, what with having had these terrible back pains and then Op on your spine etc. I think you will sail through Chemo. Ok, for lots of us it was/is tough but for me the fear of the unknown was worst (i could take the nausea, which wasn't worse than sailing in a Force 4 ). With hindsight I was far too worried about every little ache and pain. I know you have to ring the treaded number if your temperature goes up, but I was taking my temperature at least 10 times a day and sometimes wonder if I really needed to be admitted to hospital 3 times for antibiotic infusions. There is so much good advice on here to prevent mouth sores ( i suffered with these a lot, they usually appeared 8 days after Chemo). I always felt really well again two weeks after Chemo, more or less normal!  I wish you all the best, listen to your body but don't get paranoid, like me!
Posts.Title: Hello, I have just joined this group.

Posts.Content: Hello JRIP, I was diagnosed with TN 16 months ago, went through Chemo, Lumpectomy and lymphnodes removal and then Rads. It was quite a tough time.  I know what you mean, friends and family tell you that you are going to be Ok, but you want to shout, yes but I have TN.  But the longer time goes on the more positive I am. There is an interesting Facebook site (american but with ladies from all over the world). Tripe Negative Cancer Survivors There are ladies on there who are long term survivors. And it's a good site to have a quick friendly chat.  I swnd you my best wishes.
Posts.Title: Triple negative survivors , taxotere survivors shout out

Posts.Content: Great news Mrs Beezley. I had the same news two months ago, isnt it the best feeling ever, after a year of struggle and uncertainty.
Posts.Title: Fantastic News!

Posts.Content: Hello Daft Bird, I have been following your postings and love the way you think. I am new to this site and still feel my way around it! (I don't seem to be able to post a new topic). I was interested to read that you beat Non Hodgkins Lymphoma, for which I was tested and had the Bone Marrow aspiration and CT scan. The Bone Marrow and Blood Test showed Ok but a breast lump was detected. I had a Biopsy on Wednesday and I am waiting for the result. At the moment I am in this fragile state of still hoping. I am glad I found this forum and I love your positive attitude.
Posts.Title: Time between lumpectomy and chemo?

Posts.Content: Hello Daft Bird and Dreamthief, Thank you for your replies. I just checked out your instruction Dreamthief, and it works, hurray. Will be posting a new topic soon. I have so many questions I don't know where to begin.
Posts.Title: Time between lumpectomy and chemo?

Posts.Content: Thank you for the explanation of the various vertigo. Yes, mine is really bad walking up and down isles in shops, Julia. My mother always had really bad dizzy spells, but she never went to the doctor, but I think she had vertigo and I am taking it as being genetic. There are lots of exersises on you tube, I might try some of these.
Posts.Title: Vertigo after treatment

Posts.Content: Your post, Maggie, prompted me to have my dizziness checked out. Whenever I go for walks, or shopping etc. I feel really dizzy and lightheaded. This since my chemo which is 10 months back tough, but I never mentioned it to anyone.  I wondered if this could be Vertigo, do you have buzzing in the ear? I don't, and I thought that was a sign! I hope you will be able to bring it under control.
Posts.Title: Vertigo after treatment

Posts.Content: Dear Sarah. I am 67 years old and found Chemo really hard, every time I had to be admitted to 4/5 days of hospital for antibiotic infusions.  In the end: after 3 Fec and one Taxol my oncologist called a halt. It's true your mum is doing so well, just staying out of hospital. Of course I would never encourage anybody to finish with Chemo early, but if it becomes intolerable it might be the best thing. If she can continue, with your help, the better. My oncologist said that there is a new school of thought that four cycles can be enough. I had chemo before Op and my tumour shrunk considerably. So that might have influenced the decision which was made by the whole team, oncologist, consultant and surgeon.  I wish your mum and you all the best and lots of strength.
Posts.Title: my mum is struggling with chemo

Posts.Content: I am always hesitant to write about my experience with chemo (I only could tolerate four). Ask your oncologist about the new school of thought that four rounds could be enough! Do what they recommend, they are the experts. Mine wouldn't have allowed me to go on!  I send you my best wishes. Let us know what your new oncologist said.
Posts.Title: Advice / Feedback please on stopping chemo

Posts.Content: Ha, ha, Ena Sharpels and hand grenades!! I had it cut twice, everytime I think that all the curls have gone, but they come back. I wondered if it is the damp living by the sea as the structure of the hair is definitely different. I have now also snow white hair, and have not coloured it yet. It's so easy not having to colour it every 6 weeks, but I am tempted!
Posts.Title: Does anyone have curly chemo hair ?

Posts.Content: Oh grey bird, I know how you feel. It is a slap in the face and changes your life.  I just wanted to go and hide and not tell anybody. Now everybody knows, which I think was easier for my family, because they could talk openly about it (my husband said he never had so many people talking to him when out shopping and it helped him to talk about it). I want to set up a group. I know this would have helped me. Anybody live in Dorset on this forum?  I send you lots and lots of good vibes.
Posts.Title: I didn't see this coming!

Posts.Content: I did have some counselling and like your husband , Di, my husband does not believe in counselling. it did help me a little, but I was disappointed that the counsellor did not have a formula which would help me then and there and it cost £ 40 for one hour.  In the course 'Moving forward' we were told that we could have Counselling session any time through the NHS. If I just would have known that at the time. Perhaps you should talk to your GP and he could give you something to get you over this difficult time. I send you my best wishes. Many of us have been in that place.
Posts.Title: Feeling so angry tired and weak

Posts.Content: Hello George, my blod count was always low, so I always had to have the injection. Two days after chemo the district nurse came for seven days to administer them. Inspite of them I came down with non specofic infections. I would question the oncologist especially as you had no problems so far. Or ask the BC nurse to question it for you.  I send you my best wishes.
Posts.Title: G scf ,help

Posts.Content: I was sent a similar article by a friend, when I was diagnosed. I have not had any dairy products, apart from the odd yoghurt for years, due to high cholestrol, and it happened to me.  I agree with Dreamthief, and a good motto is: everything in moderation, a good well balanced diet.  And a little of what you fancy!
Posts.Title: DAIRY FOODS HIT BREAST CANCER RECOVERY

Posts.Content: The same as me Juju, I can't take any medication, as my cancer is not hormone dependent. I had Soja milk for years but that's not that good after menopause and now have Almond milk or Coconut milk, eat  ocasionally natural yoghurt and small amounts of cheese but I am more careful with refined sugar and no longer eat a whole bag of Jelly Babies. I only eat dark chocolate and  make puddings with sugar substitute or agave syrup or manuka honey. I did join a group on facebook who fight their cancer with a carbofree diet, similar to an Atkins diet, but tha's near impossible and I lost too much weight.
Posts.Title: DAIRY FOODS HIT BREAST CANCER RECOVERY

Posts.Content: Dear Angela, I am pleased you have come onto this site, there are such lovely ladies on here and of course George, Dreamthief, who is our guru, he has so much information at his fingertips. I am sure you are right, us older ladies do perhaps not get as much help as the younger ones, but I think perhaps we are of a generation, we don't like asking for help. I still regret not having asked for counselling. In our follow on course we were told that this is ready available. If I just would have asked, this would have helped.  You sound though very upbeat and brave, you managed all this on your own. ( I have got a husband I can moan to). I think it's important that we keep our friendships up, meet up, invite people round for tea, lunches, or you might be able to put you being an artist to good use and do sessions for interested people in homes?  I am sure you will get lots more answers. I send you lot of good wishes.
Posts.Title: Anastraloze side effects and older ladies without family.

Posts.Content: When I had the various procedures, like inserting marker, tatoowing for radiotheraphy etc. etc. and I was lying on the 'bench' i just wanted to cry out to everybody: " I didn't choose this, I am just one of the unlucky ones!" I could have just burst out in tears all the time. Mistymoley is right, keep the antidepressant, you might never need them, but it might just be a help that you have them just in case. We all have been through it, keep strong. I send my best wishes.
Posts.Title: Today has been a blurrrr

Posts.Content: The facebook site is German, so not sure if it's very useful. But there are low carb pages and also atkins diet pages. The German site is:  Keto bei Krebs (ketogene Diaet/Ernaehrung bei Krebs).  What an amazing consultant you have to recommend a specific diet. In Germany and Switzerland there is much more emphasis on diet and I have friends and family suffering from cancer who go for special diet cures in health resorts once they finished their treatment.
Posts.Title: DAIRY FOODS HIT BREAST CANCER RECOVERY

Posts.Content: I am so torn either way on this subject, while keeping a strict diet enpowers you to actively take part in the fight against cancer there is the comfort factor, which is also important for your well being.
Posts.Title: DAIRY FOODS HIT BREAST CANCER RECOVERY

Posts.Content: That is the best ever feeling. Congratulations!
Posts.Title: Another Neddy passes the finish post!

Posts.Content: I recommend it too.  I was told that  it is not necessary and causes infections. My veins really suffered, they occasionally had to make three attempts. In Germany and Switzerland a  portscath is standard procedure. My friend in Germany was horrified  to hear that they gave me chemo  through the veins.
Posts.Title: About to start chemo. Implantable port/central line?

Posts.Content: My nails got really bad after one tax. I put plasters on them so they would not lift off. Luckily I did not get an infection, but I was really careful. Just a consolation, 10 month after and my nails have recovered and are nice and strong again, better than before.
Posts.Title: Nails lifting off after one dose of taxotere

Posts.Content: Hi Denise, it looks great and such a lovely style. I have been to hairdresser once but now try to grow it, but it's all over the place, grey, thick, curly. I look forward for my fringe being longer, I hate a short fringe. But yours is definitely good and blends in really well.
Posts.Title: Took the plunge and went to hairdressers today ...

Posts.Content: How did you post your picture, Denise, I took a picture on my i pad and wanted to post it, but didn't work!
Posts.Title: Took the plunge and went to hairdressers today ...

Posts.Content: Somebody, a while back, mentioned Eurotunne Travel Insurance and recommended it!
Posts.Title: Holiday insurance Nowicantravel.co.uk

Posts.Content: Well done to you both. it's great to hear from you, i wondered how our two men were doing.
Posts.Title: It's our anniversary today

Posts.Content: I was just going to ask the same question.  I was never graded or staged, even on that first letter to my GP no mention of grade or stage. Only on my final Treatment Summary and follow up care plan it is mentioned that I am Grade 1 post Chemo.
Posts.Title: stage/ tiering system confusion

Posts.Content: Good for you, enjoy your meal and good luck with the chemo tomorrow. Not long to go!
Posts.Title: Food glorious food

Posts.Content: What news, Morcombe, i think we are all afraid of this scenario. I know that there are a few ladies on here whose treatment is pallative, but I suppose there would be more answers coming in on the 'secondary BC forum'. My thoughts are with you
Posts.Title: cancer spread

Posts.Content: This is the best BC forum! I have tried various others (foreign and english) and many of the questions never even get answered. I know we are lucky to have Dreamthief and Mistymoley and others who are always there with advice or a kind word. Thank you to all for making this such a caring place.
Posts.Title: This is the best BC forum!

Posts.Content: Ha, ha! You just made me smile Mena, So it better is Phil Schofield!
Posts.Title: New - My experience so far. Will it help you? Stage 2 + lymph; HER2...

Posts.Content: Brilliant blog Blue Roan, I admire your research etc. And Mena, you are entitled to your opinion, I agree with some of yours and some of Blue Roan. It's great to have a bit of a discussion. This forum is very tame!!!
Posts.Title: New - My experience so far. Will it help you? Stage 2 + lymph; HER2...

Posts.Content: Hello Mighty Mo, just thought to add to R's post to take the Steroids before four o'clock in the afternoon, so it won't keep you awake. I send you good wishes. Xxxx
Posts.Title: medication at home

Posts.Content: I had really fuzzy 'sideburns', removed them twice with hair removing cream, now they have gone for good ( 11 months after Chemo). Also I still have terrible night and day sweats and I am on NO medication at all since Chemo.  I had to laugh about the 'ears of a Spaniel', Jaqueline, what an apt description! My hair looks like that!
Posts.Title: I'm growing a hairy,furry face!!!

Posts.Content: Yes, Denise, it's good to have friends who go through the same and they understand what you have been through. And your experience is typical.  I find that we are now mixing a bit more with people again, invitations etc. But I have always to smile, they are all talking about my husband's bad back and rarely about me. I have not told, or had the chance to tell anybody, about my threefold experience, chemo, Op and radiotherapy. I sometimes would like to shout: what about me!
Posts.Title: Mixed day yesterday ....

Posts.Content: Oh yes, Denise, I remember now, you and your husband were in the same hospital. That must have been such a traumatic time and you sound so cheerful. I don't like to say too much to my two sons and families, they have their own worries with babies and IVF, but wish my friends would be a bit more interested, but then, I suppose, it's good that they treat me just like I never was ill.
Posts.Title: Mixed day yesterday ....

Posts.Content: What I missed most during the months of diagnosis and treatment was meeting up with other ladies who were in the same 'boat'. We have a really good Cancer Charity in our town and one of the visitors suggested that I could start my own group and they would support me. Now I have some questions which I want to clarify before I start this:   Should I only start with ladies who have breastcancer? What venue would be acceptable, local cafe or? Once a month or once a week? How should I advertise it? What would be a good name for us? Any other ideas would be welcome. Thank you in advance
Posts.Title: Should I start .......?

Posts.Content: I am like Katee and Judith, I am still processing the fact that I have/had breastcancer. My friends and family, mostly, never wanted to know that much about it. Two friends totally ignored and never talked about it or asked any questions, but gave me flowers and chocolates. I realize there are people who can't cope with illness but it does hurt. I sometimes would like to scream when some say, well you are Ok now, no I am not, I am still going through radiotherapy and what if it comes back?
Posts.Title: Fed up of cancer being the focus ...

Posts.Content: I just don't trust any of these remedies any more. When I started my cancer journey it was all flaxseed and Kale juice. Now they say, flaxseed has too many unwanted hormones and kale has to much metal in it. You do not know what to believe. With all these spice-remedies,  I ask myself how fresh they are, if they have been on the shelf too long there could be an added health risk. Am I being paranoid?
Posts.Title: Tumeric and aches and pains

Posts.Content: I was told that I must go and be measured for a compression sleeve for the arm and always wear it when flying, I wasn't told to wear flight socks but have always worn them for long flights.
Posts.Title: Flight stockings

Posts.Content: I was told that I must go and be measured for a compression sleeve for the arm and always wear it when flying, I wasn't told to wear flight socks but have always worn them for long flights.
Posts.Title: Flight stockings

Posts.Content: I wonder if it's different from surgeon to surgeon. Mine was adamant that I should be measured for a compression sleeve straight away and wear it on every flight, short or long.  I don't have lymphodema. I had a lumpectomy and lymphnodes but I had no drains.
Posts.Title: Flight stockings

Posts.Content: With my arm compression sleeve I was recommended to wear it in the morning before we set off and right until the evening. She even said to wear it the next morning. So I did the same with my flight stockings! Have a good trip, Tilly
Posts.Title: Flight stockings

Posts.Content: I wonder if it's different from surgeon to surgeon. Mine was adamant that I should be measured for a compression sleeve straight away and wear it on every flight, short or long.  I don't have lymphodema. I had a lumpectomy and lymphnodes but I had no drains.
Posts.Title: Flight stockings

Posts.Content: They also told me not to be tempted to wear a flight stocking on my arm!! :))
Posts.Title: Flight stockings

Posts.Content: With my arm compression sleeve I was recommended to wear it in the morning before we set off and right until the evening. She even said to wear it the next morning. So I did the same with my flight stockings! Have a good trip, Tilly
Posts.Title: Flight stockings

Posts.Content: They also told me not to be tempted to wear a flight stocking on my arm!! :))
Posts.Title: Flight stockings

Posts.Content: That's what I was told dear Birty and Crystaljuju, four weeks in my case, any pain or unusual symptoms. I think I have started to trust my body more one year after last Chemo. Chemo produced quite a lot of strange symptoms and I was never quite sure. But now I am back to normal it's easier to listen to your body.
Posts.Title: How do we know?

Posts.Content: Hello Lelly,  you are so welcome on this site and it's great that you are so interested. I always missed that with my sister, while she was sorry for me, she really had not much of an idea nor was she interested to learn more (the same with most of my friends). This is such a good forum and people will be only too glad to help you with their knowledge.
Posts.Title: Am I allowed to join - or would you prefer this group to be just patients...

Posts.Content: Such good news. Congratulations. I will be over the moon to get news like that, had my mammogram a week ago, do you think I should ring?
Posts.Title: Result of first mammogram today ...

Posts.Content: Hello Chloecat and ladies, I too admire you for going the non Chemo, non Surgery route. That's very much what I wanted to do, but was persuaded by family and friends to 'chuck' everything at it which the medical world offers. I also belong to  a ketogenic facebook group (they advocate a diet of meat, high fat cheese, cream etc. and many vegetables and fruit are banned and no carbs). I tried this for a while but lost so much weight. I now just stay off high sugar snacks and drinks. I I went through chemo and surgery and start radiotheraphy soon. I think if the cancer comes back in the future I will not tell anyone and go down the alternative route. Perhaps Mistletoe injections and go back to the ketogenic diet. For the time being I am glad I did try the 'medical' route, because I would have always questioned myself, what if?  I wish you lots of success, it sounds as if you are doing well. Keep in contact. I will follow this thread.  Monika
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: I send you many good wishes. I was surprised how well I felt after.
Posts.Title: First Chemo Today - Moral Support Request

Posts.Content: Hello Liz,  welcome to this great forum. I am way past treatment but still come on here. I also belong to a great FB site: Triple Negative Cancer Survivors. It's an American site but international. It's more instant than a forum, you get an answer very quickly. If you have any trouble to join, let me know.  If I would have to go through Chemo again, I would buy a wig (you could probably have one made out of your lovely long hair). I would go for a hairstyle I always dreamed about. Scarves and hats get so boring. And on Strictly come Dancing I always admire the ladies when they wear wigs, they look better somehow!  I wish you all the best. You sound very positive.
Posts.Title: Hello Newbie Here

Posts.Content: I have followed you right through your journey with your son and then his passing. You have gone through so much, including the breastcancer.    I wish you lots of strength.
Posts.Title: Our Arron's Death Certificate came yesterday

Posts.Content: Yes Leona, you have the correct FB group, I forgot the BC.  I will look out for you.
Posts.Title: Hello Newbie Here

Posts.Content: Good for you Sally I can sense your fighting spirit.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Round 2-Triple Negative

Posts.Content: I was thinking of you catchpole and wondered how you got on. I was also questioning the surgeon and wondered it it would not be better to have a masectomy. But she assured me, that statistically seen it's just as good to have only a lumpectomy, which is much better, you probably will be out of hospital the same day. ( I had Op at eight and was out 2 pm). I had Chemo before Op and then radiotheraphy, who knows, you might not need Chemo. Take each step as it comes. I send you my best wishes.
Posts.Title: Saw Surgeon

Posts.Content: Caroline, What kind of a massage? Would there be a link to internet? I am still numb!   I take part in that study, but the nurses taking the measurements are not very knowledgeable.    It would be great if you could describe the technique.
Posts.Title: Saw Surgeon

Posts.Content: So true, Nannymary.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Round 2-Triple Negative

Posts.Content: Great to read your posts. This is my biggest worry. I started Chemo on the 10th of June. I just couldn't make a decision about the cold cap treatments and in a way regret it. I am now just a bit worried for the second chemo. Is it getting worse as Chemo progresses? You are all so wonderfully positive. A great tonic.   Monika
Posts.Title: Hair worries

Posts.Content: Yes, Nannymary, great reply. I had TN. Treatment is behind me. I do dwell on 'what if' but will print out your reply to remind be to be positive. I worry quite a bit, because I couldnt' t finish my Chemo because I felt so poorly. Apparently Triple Negative, from all other form of BC, responds best to Chemo. My BC nurse said to put that on my fridge!
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Round 2-Triple Negative

Posts.Content: Hello Bellaboo, the same with me, no scans or bloodwork after all the treatments ceased. I was told if I had a pain anywhere in my body, or a cough etc. for longer than 4 weeks to have it checked out.  I think with time we learn to trust our bodies again and realise we are more resilient than we thought.
Posts.Title: How do you know if you have mets

Posts.Content: I am not very often on this Forum anymore, but got notification by e-mail of this thread and I was shocked to read that your wife has got her wings. So, so sad. We are all afraid of this scenario.  You were such a beautiful husband, coming on here and talking about it and find an answer shows that.  I wish you much strength and send you and your family lots of hugs.
Posts.Title: Getting really scary now.

Posts.Content: I am so sorry for this development. Right back in October 2014, you must have already suspected that you willl have to deal with something more serious. But what a shock this must be. Also these letters from the consultant to the GP sound so cold and heartless.   There is a forum: secondary breast cancer. I sometimes have a look on there and have seen ladies who live quite a full life with mets.  My thoughts are with you and your wife. I think she is very lucky to have you at her side.
Posts.Title: Getting really scary now.

Posts.Content: Dear Katee, I would ring BC nurse but I had/ have the same as you, I always feel swollen, especially towards evening and this is 6 months after surgery. Oncologist suggested that I massage lightly ( there are some instructions on you tube). I do the excersises but perhaps not enough. If your arm, wrist and hand are swollen I would start worrying about lymphodema, thst's what Oncologist said. I am taking part in a study for lymphodema and was told on Friday that all was well. I think the swelling is due to the lymphdrainage being impaired and will settled down in time!
Posts.Title: Swollen arm/breast is it normal?

Posts.Content: I have real problems getting on this forum. If I sign in, it does not take me directly back to forum. It used to be fine but been playing up for some time.  I sometimes have to go 'all round the houses' again'. I wouldn't mind staying signed in; is that possible and how?  Administration: couldn't we have a facebook site, closed group, much more immediated and user friendly.
Posts.Title: problems getting on forum?

Posts.Content: This is the only area of my treatment I am not happy with, lack of information, I would have liked to see my CT scan where the BC was detected and then my mammography and ultrasound. I am now in denial! I think my diagnosis was a mistake. I would like Mcmillan to stand up for us and demand more transparency.
Posts.Title: How do I get copy of pathology report?

Posts.Content: You are so right Crystaljuju. And I suppose to make everything available to the patients would cost a lot of money. I love your posts. Are you in a medical profession?
Posts.Title: How do I get copy of pathology report?

Posts.Content: Hi G n'J, that worked! Thank you so much. Just need to find widget to keep me signed in.n I know what you mean about 'searchable'. That's why questions are put over and over again on Fb. But I don't mind that so much, as there are always new interesting posts.
Posts.Title: problems getting on forum?

Posts.Content: Great news!
Posts.Title: Swollen arm/breast is it normal?

Posts.Content: I am still losing weight and I am back to eating really well. I am a little worried about that. I had started on a sugar and carbofree diet but lost too much, so now I am eating everything, including cakes and chocolate which I like again. Usually weight loss is an underlying sign of some illness, I will ask consultant when I see her on Wednesday.
Posts.Title: Weight loss continues after treatment well finished.

Posts.Content: Great Mike!
Posts.Title: My last FEC treatment was a year ago today!

Posts.Content: Wow, that could change our lives. I just had tears in my eyes, too late for us on here as we have been or are already treated, but great for the future. I was quite shocked how many young women were in that video. thanks for posting the link.
Posts.Title: You may have seen this , but it is worth a look ..

Posts.Content: Thank You so much Butterfly, I have a mammography appointment in June and was told that if a pain or symptoms persists for several weeks to contact them or the GP. I have a nagging backache so wonder if I should, but I think I am just over worried. But it is so good to be told that you are without cancer. Probably, like me, a year ago, we were still blissfully unaware what a rollercoaster year would expect us. I wish you all the best.
Posts.Title: oncology appointment

Posts.Content: Congratulations. Such a good feeling.
Posts.Title: its official

Posts.Content: Hello Carole, I am not writing on here much these days either, two years after diagnosis, but I had a scare like you not long ago, a very small lump near the lumpectomy scar. I telephoned my Breastcare nurse immediately and had an ultrasound a few days later. I got an immediate, unofficial result it being scar tissue and the official result a few days later. I am sure you will experience same. I will be thinking about you.
Posts.Title: Another Lump

Posts.Content: Hello Katee, I had my Op 4 month ago, 2 cm lump and 17 Lymphnodes removed. Two incisions. Op went well with clear margins. I was warned that a second Op might be needed, but was relieved that all was removed. At the moment I do ask myself if I can ever play tennis again. I am still numb and my movements are still impaired. I am taking part in a study for lymphodema and I was told that all was well. Like Sally, I wear gloves for household chores and I am careful not to injure this arm. Put lots of E 45 on as well. I wasn't very good with excercing, it just hurt too much, but now I am doing weight excersises with a bag of sugar. This has really helped, I think my mobility is coming back.  I wish you all the best with your Op. That bit I quite enjoyed, especially waking up from anasthetic and having a cup of tea and toast.
Posts.Title: Lymph node removal and under arm nerve

Posts.Content: Lindt Milk chocolate and Toblerone, but then I am Swiss!!
Posts.Title: Diet & Chocolate for nutritional purposes ;-D

Posts.Content: Hello Butterfly, what I really wanted to know most, as there were no post treatment scans and bloodtest, how I would recognize if the cancer has spread. You can see I am not the most optimistic person. It would be interesting to see what your oncologist would say!
Posts.Title: oncology appointment

Posts.Content: Well done, that's the toughest bit of the journey. From now on it's all uphill. You can be proud of yourself. Lots of best wishes for the surgery and perhaps radiotherapy.
Posts.Title: Last chemo done, 3 x FEC and 3 x Taxatere. Done! finito!!

Posts.Content: Sorry Yvonne, that must be awful. I have had the flu jab and luckily not have picked up anything yet although lots of people are suffering, apparently with a new flu strain.  I thought that perhaps no virus can survive in my Chemo body that's why I hadn't picked up anything!!
Posts.Title: Head cold from hell

Posts.Content: Oh I know how you feel, Powderpuff, about the twinges in your body and being scared. I was told that if you feel a pain longer than 4 weeks to go and see GP, I thought that was good advice. I did not have any more screening, CT or MRI or bloodtest after finishing treatment, yesterday I had my first mammography, 6 months after.  Rereading your post, you are at a different stage, but I left my posting just as a bit of info for the future  You will be fine, it's a very small percentage of us ladies who have further issues after we finish treatment. I send you good vibes.
Posts.Title: Feeling Lost

Posts.Content: Today I had the result of my mammograms (6 months after treatment), it was worded as follows: I write with the result of bilateral mammograms performed on 23rd June 2015. I am pleased to say that these show no worrying features.  Dare I believe it? After a year of being in and out of hospital: Chemo, 4 x admitted with Infections, OP and radiotherapy.  I want to join the Neddy Club!
Posts.Title: No worrying features!

Posts.Content: So interesting, your post Smoothie, I was always afraid of being overtreated. After my first chemo (before op) and landing in hospital neutropenic, I wrote a long letter to my consultant saying that I did not want to continue with Chemo but would much rather have a complete masectomy.  I have a theory, that nowadays it's the 'belt and braces' approach to make absolutely sure. I have two friends who had masectomies twenty years ago and they never had chemo nor were they on hormone inhibitors.  In the end I had three FEC and one T because my family persuaded me. My treatment summary says that the tumour shrunk from 20mm to 13mm Grade 1 and node positive 1 out of 17. So I guess it did some good! My mammogram which I had a week ago will show!!
Posts.Title: Post op appointment yesterday

Posts.Content: Hello Puzzle, sorry to hear that you have lymphodema but there is a lot you can do about it. Ask to be transferred to the lymphodema clinic, there you will have a long appointment with the lymphodema nurse. I was adviced to do massages and got a DVD to learn, I got little cushions with beads to put in vest to massage my breast.  The next step, if it doesn't get better is taping it with plasters, I think it's called kynetic? One lady I met on 'Moving forward' was very enthusiastic about this. Have you got a compression sleeve? Wear this for all excersise, don't do work over your head, paint ceilings, hang curtains, prune trees etc. you could also be described a compression vest. (I am better without bra and wear a support vest, but I have Kira Kneitley size boobs).  I hope this helps, Puzzle.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with Lymphoedema in breast - need advice

Posts.Content: Hello, I just had to write to you. I am so pleased for you because you went through some rough times. Keep on sailing!
Posts.Title: Something good for a change

Posts.Content: Dear Ro, I feel with you, because I am awaiting result to see if I need second Op. I will be really depressed if the answer is yes, especially now it's all nicely healing and I am getting more mobile again. I am also taking part in that trial limphodema, I had to go and have various tests before the Op and have another appointment on the 30th. Let me know how you get on.
Posts.Title: 2nd op for lymph node removal after mastectomy

Posts.Content: Maggie may, I agree, but this must be more than a suicide, perhaps something like Breivik who committed the massacre in Norway. We will never be able to understand this, it's just too terrible. It must be just too awful for family and friends.
Posts.Title: why?

Posts.Content: Oh alicemay, I think we are all worried about this scenario. Ok, I was worried before I even was diagnosed but now I am scared! Let's hope you will be fine, they are probably just being extra careful. I send you many hugs too.
Posts.Title: Mammogram

Posts.Content: Lovely said Fiona. I am just cooking the Christmas Feast but see: I can't be without you lovely ladies.
Posts.Title: Petrified waiting for results

Posts.Content: I posted my thank you for your hug on your other post. But thank you again. It helps! I was diagnosed last May and have finished all treatment end of December. Because I am Triple Negative no more Meds. I send you lots of good wishes.
Posts.Title: Mammogram

Posts.Content: Dear Peace,  I am so sorry you have to go through this at Christmas.  But don't forget nine out of ten "investigations" result in a benign verdict. It's a shame they didn't tell you over the phone, but even if the news is good, which I am sure it is, they like to tell you face to face. Don't worry. Take it step by step. This is a great forum with lovely ladies. I am sure you will be able to tell us good news after you seen your consultant on Wednesday.  I send you my best wishes for a happy Christmas.
Posts.Title: Petrified waiting for results

Posts.Content: Dear Julie, yes I receive steroids, I was told it helps with the sickness. It makes me a little lively, so I take the evening one at four in the afternoon. I know how you feel, haha!! I am bald. Lost my hair 10 day after the first Chemo. My husband has a really 'black humor' and thinks it's funny! I wish you all the best. You are in Spain. Wow, your Spanish must be pretty good.   Love,   Monika
Posts.Title: steroids

Posts.Content: Dear Patsy Plum, what a difficult situatuion you describe, I would have wanted to scream: I am not here for my own enjoyment!! I had a similar experience, in as much as they sent me for a totally unnecessary painful procedure when my gallstones were investigated. Luckily we all realised it five minutes before, that there was a mistake from the consultant. Do you have a BC nurse, could you ask her to investigate it.  I wish you all the best.
Posts.Title: Confused and upset

Posts.Content: Hello Loolou, what a decision. Like Julia with Tripe Negative I didn't have a choice and had to have, although in the end I had only four (3 fec and one T), because as the oncologist said, we don't want to kill you!  As you have been given the choice, I would happily decide not to have chemo. Chemo has so many negatives and it's not the 'cure' as such! You need also to have trust in the healing power of your body. I again don't want to persuade you for or against. Even for the oncologist this is a difficult decision. I wish that you have the best outcome/decision possible.
Posts.Title: help needed re chemo or not

Posts.Content: Well done, not long to go and all this is behind you. I found it the best feeling ever.
Posts.Title: On the last leg of this horrid journey

Posts.Content: Hello Mysteryleo, I had the same Triple Negative. grade 3. additionally I had one lymphnode which showed cancer. My chemo regime was FEC-T, 6 sessions three FEC and three Tax. The tumor shrunk and I was allowed to finish after three FEC and one Tax, then had lumpectomy and 17 lymphnodes cleared and radiotheraphy for 4 weeks.  After it all sunk in, this very inconvenient diagnosis of BC, I was quite looking forward for the Chemo. I wanted to see how it makes you feel! I didn't feel bad at all with the FEC apart from mouth ulcers and my blood values were never that good and twice I had to go to hospital for antibiotics, but that is just me, My mouth is my weakest point. I wish you all the best, just ask on here.
Posts.Title: TNBC - starting FEC-T chemo regime this friday advice needed

Posts.Content: Thank you for putting my mind at ease. Since Op I have experienced discomfort, exactly as described by Yvonne. Radiotherapy made it worse. I have read on a German forum that ladies are adviced to wear a t shirt turned inside out (so seams don't irritate) under the bra. This helps a bit, but looks a bit weird!!!
Posts.Title: Is this normal??

Posts.Content: That made me smile too. Thank you for sharing.
Posts.Title: Bad hair day

Posts.Content: Like crystaljuju (i think we are very similar, only she is much younger) i had lymphnode involvement, but after treatment I am NED, no evidence of disease.  I thought that the CT scan was quite relaxing and I would not mind having another one.  There is a really so much hope for breastcancer nowadays, but I know how you feel, a year ago I wouldn't have believed it either. I send you so many good wishes.
Posts.Title: Partner has just been diagnosed with Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks mistymoley, just put the book on my kindle. Will be captivating reading on a boring journey. (I am going to see my family in Switzerland, it will be quite emotional,  hurray I am healed!)
Posts.Title: Is it just me ...

Posts.Content: So true, that was me 6 month ago. It will get better I promise you. I took quite a few sleeping tablets and did not get hooked. I slept very well after Chemo and after Op, but now on radiotherapy I have sleepless nights again without the nightmares (are you at the radiotherapy stage Liddyloo? Do you think it gives you insomnia?) I wish you all the best, the good thing is, that it will pass and the human mind is wonderful in forgetting. I think when I finish radiotheraphy on Wednesday I will be quite at a loss, I will be out there on my own, without any hospital appointments for 6 weeks.
Posts.Title: The hideous midnight hour...

Posts.Content: Hello Mrt,  it's such a shock for both of you and it's great you help your partner on the important road to recovery. I say 'recovery' because statistics shows that most women nowadays recover, it's treatable. This is my most important advice, keep focused, I had terrible thoughts, especially at night, but After Chemo, OP and radiotheraphy I am NED, no evidence of disease. You will be there in a few months time and your partner and you will come out if it better and stronger.
Posts.Title: Partner has just been diagnosed with Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: This is very interesting and I have often thought, that certain posts on FB,  are either brave or too much in your face. When I was diagnosed I odered a book from Amazon about an actress, I think it  was Vanessa Redgrave's sister, who was photographed by her daughter over several month going through masectomy. I never even unpacked it. I just couldn't. (If anybody wants it you could send me your address, but I don't know if there is a Personal message board?).  I feel that the cause - breastcancer research/awareness- must not alienate people by too agressive canvassing. That would be a shame.
Posts.Title: Is it just me ...

Posts.Content: You will cope. Think of yourself as a Super Warrior Woman, ready for the battle.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed yesterday - need mastectomy August 19th :-O

Posts.Content: So well done, I have been following you from day one. Now you can relax and get your life back, isn't it a wonderful feeling.
Posts.Title: I did it too!

Posts.Content: I hope you feel better soon, all of you on here who have the flu. I heard on the news yesterday that there is a new flu type around where the jab is ineffective.
Posts.Title: G n j

Posts.Content: Oh Kath, you live in France, I saw one of your  interesting posting about treatment abroad. It's interesting how you get treated in other countries, that's why i joined a forum in Germany. Up to now I have found that the health care staff  are really friendly (although in a rush in the rad dep and not communicative). and also they never lecture you, while in Germany patients do get told exactly what to do, which annoys some.
Posts.Title: Last Radiotherapy today.

Posts.Content: Thank you for the really useful answers on here. I just looked up the yoga pose Lemurgirlpurple, will definitely try this because I am having my first docetaxel next Tuesday after the three FEC., and I am pretty scared, because I read some reports .... I know I shouldn't google!!    Any other advice for the Docetaxel course would be much appreciated Lemurgirlpurple, but I don't want to hijack the intitial posting.
Posts.Title: I am a Newby......and potential guinea pig!!!!!!!

Posts.Content: So  envious, Mandy, I just started yesterday, everyday two hours drive there and back? Although the radio therapy is not painful or distressing, it's all so impersonal. I found the Chemo care team friendlier. I am sure something was wrong with the machine, almost an hour late and  I was waiting for the 'beam' for over 15 Minutes once they left the room. This will be a Christmas I never forget!
Posts.Title: Last Radiotherapy today.

Posts.Content: No,  not at Christies. What a nightmare for you with the accident as well.  Yes Kath, I shed a tear (secretly) yesterday  as I was lying under that machine, whirring and frizzling. I kept on thinking: I didn't ask for this and why me? But otherwise I do feel much more positive! Christmas and New Year week I have only three teeatments each. Finish before 2015. I hope it will be a better year.  I wish you all the best and lots of luck with your treatment.
Posts.Title: Last Radiotherapy today.

Posts.Content: That's the news I am afraid of. I always wanted a masectomy just to be sure but surgeon assured me that a lumpectomy was fine. You sound like you are a strong girl and have stength and stamina. I was told by several friends, why did  I not insist on masectomy! I send you lots of good wishes.
Posts.Title: Disappointment

Posts.Content: That's the news I am afraid of. I always wanted a masectomy just to be sure but surgeon assured me that a lumpectomy was fine. You sound like you are a strong girl and have stength and stamina. I was told by several friends, why did  I not insist on masectomy! I send you lots of good wishes.
Posts.Title: Disappointment

Posts.Content: Dear Lou, I feel so much with you, but Javron has explained it really well. I was admitted three times during my Chemo in the summer (yours is even worse because it was Christmas). I was always devastated, when my temperature shot up because I knew I would end up in hospital yet again. The nurses used to say: not you again!!! Just like you, I was petrified, especially at night. I thought I would have long term effects from all the chemo and the antibiotics. But I can reassure you, I am really well again now. No long term effects at all and we are even making jokes about it now!! The postponement of the Chemo is annoying, but it's better that your immune system is in top form again, a week here or there doesn't matter in the great scheme of things.  I wish you, dear Lou, all the best. I send you many good vibes. You will soon have it all behind you.     Monika
Posts.Title: Neutropenic
